tit.e: Kyo no Daibutsu (Great Buddha Statues in Kyoto)
Kyo no Daibutsu (Great Buddha Statues in Kyoto)

sen.j: 京の大仏（きょうのだいぶつ）は、方広寺（京都市東山区）にかつて存在した大仏。
sen.e: Kyo no Daibutsu originally existed in Hoko-ji Temple (Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City).
Kyo no Daibutsu originally existed in Hoko-ji Temple (Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City).

sen.j: 江戸時代には日本三大大仏に数えられた。
sen.e: It was counted as one of the three great statues of Buddha in Japan.
It was counted as one of the three great statues of Buddha in Japan.
It was counted as one of the three great statues of Great Buddha in Japan.

sen.j: ここでは、大仏と大仏殿について述べる。
sen.e: Daibutsu and Daibutsuden (the Great Buddha hall) will be stated here.

sen.j: 秀吉による造営
sen.e: Construction by Hideyoshi
Construction by Hideyoshi
Construction by Hideyoshi

sen.j: 天正14年（1586年）、豊臣秀吉は奈良の東大寺にならって大仏の建立を計画し、大仏殿と大仏の造営を始めた。
sen.e: Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI planned the construction of Daibutsuden and Daibutsu following the example of Todai-ji Temple of Nara in 1586.
Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI planned the construction of Daibutsuden and Daibutsu following the example of Todai-ji Temple of Nara in 1586.
Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI planned the construction of Daibutsuden and the Great Buddha following the example of Todai-ji Temple of Nara in 1586.

sen.j: 文禄4年（1595年）、大仏殿がほぼ完成し、高さ約19メートルの木製金漆塗坐像大仏が安置されたが、慶長元年（1596年）に起きた大地震により、開眼供養前の大仏は倒壊した。
sen.e: Daibutsuden was mostly completed and nineteen meters high wooden great Buddha statue decorated with lacquer and gold was set up in 1595 but collapsed due to the great earthquake in 1596 before a ceremony to consecrate a newly made Buddhist statue was held.

Daibutsuden was mostly completed and nineteen meters high wooden great Buddha statue decorated with lacquer and gold was set up in 1595 but collapsed due to the great earthquake in 1596 before a ceremony to consecrate a newly made Buddhist statue was held.

Daibutsuden was mostly completed and approximately 19 meters high wooden Great Buddha statue decorated with lacquer and gold was set up in 1595 but collapsed due to the great earthquake in 1596 before a ceremony to consecrate a newly made Buddhist statue was held.

sen.j: 慶長3年（1598年）、秀吉は大仏開眼供養を待たずに死去し、同年大仏のない大仏殿で開眼供養が行われた。
sen.e: Hideyoshi passed away in 1598 before a ceremony to consecrate a newly made Buddhist statue, and the service was held in Daibutsuden without Daibutsu in the same year.
Hideyoshi passed away in 1598 before a ceremony to consecrate a newly made Buddhist statue, and during the same year the service was held in Daibutsuden without Daibutsu.
Hideyoshi passed away in 1598 before a ceremony to consecrate a newly made Buddhist statue, and during the same year the service was held in Daibutsuden without Great Buddha.

sen.j: 大仏殿は高さ約49メートル、南北約88メートル、東西約54メートルという壮大なものであり、また境内は、現在の方広寺境内のみならず、豊国神社_(京都市)、京都国立博物館を含むものであった。
sen.e: Daibutsuden had an enormous height of forty-nine meters, width of eighty-eight meters south to north, fifty-four meters east to west, and precincts of a shrine included not only Hoko-ji Temple, Toyokoku Shrine (Kyoto City), and Kyoto National Museum.

The enormous Daibutsuden was 49 meters tall, 88 meters wide south to north and 54 meters deep east to west, and the precincts of the shrine included not only Hoko-ji Temple but also Toyokoku Shrine (Kyoto City) and the Kyoto National Museum.

The enormous Daibutsuden was approximately 49 meters tall, 88 meters wide south to north and 54 meters deep east to west, and the precincts of the temple included not only Hoko-ji Temple but also Toyokuni-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City) and the Kyoto National Museum.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 秀頼による造営
sen.e: Construction by Hideyori

sen.j: 秀吉の子豊臣秀頼が遺志を継ぎ、片桐且元を中心に今度は銅製で大仏の再建を行ったが、慶長7年（1602年）11月、鋳物師の過失による仏像が融解して出火し、大仏殿は炎上した。
sen.e: Hideyori TOYOTOMI, who was the son of Hideyoshi, took after his will and attempted the reconstruction of Daibutsu in copper with Katsumoto KATAGIRI as the center, but Buddhist statue melt due to the error of caster and Daibutsuden was caught in blaze in November 1602

Hideyori TOYOTOMI, who was the son of Hideyoshi, succeeded his father and attempted the reconstruction of Daibutsu in copper with Katsumoto KATAGIRI as the center, but the Buddhist statue melt due to an error by the caster and Daibutsuden was caught in a blaze in November 1602.

Hideyori TOYOTOMI, who was the son of Hideyoshi, succeeded his father and attempted the reconstruction of Great Buddha in copper with Katsumoto KATAGIRI as the leader, but the Buddhist statue melt due to an error by the caster and Daibutsuden was caught in a blaze in December 1602.

sen.j: 慶長13年（1608年）10月には再び大仏および大仏殿の再建が企図された。
sen.e: There was a plan brought up again to reconstruct Daibutsu and Daibutsuden in October 1608.

sen.j: 大仏殿の創建は慶長15年（1610年）から行われ、徳川家康も諸大名に扶持負担などを命じ、自身も米の供与や大工中井正清を送っている。
sen.e: The construction of Daibutsuden was carried out from 1610, and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA ordered the various daimyo to support nearby and sent Masakiyo NAKAI, who was the carpenter while he himself donated rice.
The construction of Daibutsuden was begun in 1610; Ieyasu TOKUGAWA ordered the various nearby daimyo to support it and sent Masakiyo NAKAI, who was the carpenter, while he himself donated rice.

sen.j: また、大仏に張られる金の板金は江戸で鋳造されている(『当代記』）。
sen.e: Furthermore, the sheet metal used to stick to the daibutsu was casted in Edo ("Todaiki").
Furthermore, the sheet metal in which the daibutsu was clad was cast in Edo ("Todaiki").
Furthermore, the golden plate in which the Great Buddha was clad was cast in Edo ("Todaiki" (a famous chronicle describing the Early Modern age)).

sen.j: 6月には地鎮祭が行われ、大仏殿と銅製の大仏は慶長17年（1612年）に完成した。
sen.e: The ground-breaking ceremony was performed in June, and Daibutsuden and Daibutsu made from copper were completed in 1612.
The ground-breaking ceremony was performed in June, and the Daibutsuden and Daibutsu made from copper were completed in 1612.
The ground-breaking ceremony was performed in July, and the Daibutsuden and the Great Buddha made from copper were completed in 1612.

sen.j: 慶長19年（1614年）には４月大仏殿の造営にあたり梵鐘が完成し、南禅寺の禅僧文英清韓に命じて銘文を起草させ落慶供養を行おうとしたところ、7月には梵鐘の銘文について徳川家康より不吉な語句があるとして異議が唱えられ、開眼供養の中止を求めた。
sen.e: The bosho (Buddhist temple bell) was completed in Daibutusden in April, 1614 and when rakkei hoyo (a memorial service to celebrate the construction of a temple) was held but was aborted due to an ill-omened word mentioned by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA in July concerning inscription for a Buddhist temple bell drafted by the Zen monk Bunei Seikan of Nanzen-ji Temple.

sen.j: なお、その後寛文2年（1662年）の地震で小破し、大仏は木造で造り直されることになった。
sen.e: In addition, Daibutsu was destroyed a little by the earthquake of 1662 and was to be reconstructed with wood.
Additionally, Daibutsu was damaged in the earthquake of 1662 and was thus to be reconstructed with wood.

sen.j: 壊れた大仏の銅は寛永通宝の鋳造に用いられたといわれる。
sen.e: The copper from the destroyed daibutsu is said to be used in the casting of Kanei Tsuho (coins).
The copper from the ruined daibutsu is said to have been used in the casting of Kanei Tsuho (coins).

sen.j: 寛政10年（1798年）の7月に大仏殿に落雷。

sen.e: The main hall, Sanmon burnt down and the wooden Daibutsu also reduced to ashes.
The main hall, Sanmon, burned down and the wooden Daibutsu was reduced to ashes.

sen.j: 「京の大仏つぁんは天火で焼けてな、三十三間堂が焼け残った、どんどんどん、こらどんどんどん」という京都のわらべ歌はこの時の火災のことを歌っている。
sen.e: The songs for children of Kyoto sings of this fire, 'Daibutsu of Kyo burned due to the tenka (fire from lightening) and Sanjusangendo Temple left, aradondondon (don-don-yake (it was a word commonly used by Kyoto citizens for the rapidly spread fire started from a fire at the time of Kinmon Incident)), koradondon.'
